text:
Leicestershire hits 32C making it hotter than Barbados By SamCFisher | Posted: July 19, 2016 0 COMMENTS SHARES Effie Young, two, cools down in a paddling pool during the hot weather Leicestershire hits 32C making it hotter than Barbados X 
Copy link to paste in your message / 
With temperatures reaching a scorching 32C today, the city and county were hotter than Barbados. 
Temperatures here were three degrees higher than the Caribbean island. 
It was the hottest day of the year for us so far - and we have not experienced those temperatures since July last year. 
Mercury weatherman Dave Mutton said: "I have 35C on July 1 last year. That is the last time we have had temperatures this high. 
"Today was certainly the hottest day of this year without a doubt." 
He added that tomorrow will still be hot, with temperatures about 29C, with showers developing later on. 
"From tomorrow afternoon through to Thursday morning there will be thunderstorms which will clear the atmosphere. 
"Temperatures by Friday will be 21C, back to normal. 20C to 21C is normal for this time of year. 
"Then I can't see any other really hot weather for a fortnight." 
Some businesses in the city and county including ice cream sellers and Leicestershire's only outdoor swimming pool were doing a booming trade. 
The outdoor pool at Hood Park Leisure Centre, in Ashby, was at full capacity. 
Duncan Gibb, commercial manager for Hermitage and Hood Park Leisure Centres, said: "It's extremely hot and the pool was very busy to the point we were full to capacity on three occasions today. 
"This is the first time in two years we have been full. 
"More than 300 people have been through the door." 
A barbeque and music added to the party atmosphere.

He added: "Because the pool has a wall around it, I always say on a day like today, you really could be abroad - you can't recognise you are in Ashby. 
"The atmosphere is fantastic. There is an awful lot of joyful banter and parents seem to be happy to top up their sun tan." 
Daniele Taverna, co-founder of Gelato Village, in St Martin's Square, Leicester, said sales were up roughly 30 per cent. 
He said: "Many more people are around and the product we sell is refreshing - it does increase sales." 
Kieron Parker, who works for Steve's Ices, was in selling ice cream in Leicester. 
He said it was like a greenhouse working in the ice cream van as it is made of plastic and refrigerators were letting off heat. 
"It is much hotter in here than outside." 
He said sales were up by about one third today. 
Volunteer steam train driver Bill Brazier, 76, had to brave temperatures nudging 40C as he shovelled coal into a steam loco. 
Today he worked from 6.30am to 4.30pm making three trips from Loughborough to Leicester North station and back on the Great Central Railway. 
He took it in turns with the fireman, Bob Littler, to shovel coal into the furnace. 
He said with the temperature about 30C outside, where he was working in the engine it would have been closer to 40C. 
Bill said: "You could not get much hotter than what I was doing. 
"It has been ridiculously hot. It's almost unbearable temperatures like this, but of course, the old guys used to do it years ago." 
He said he just wanted to get home and get into the bath. 
"I found it very tiring - I am absolutely whacked. It is hard and physical, but I enjoy doing it. 
"In the winter, it is lovely because you're next to a really hot fire." 
Bill volunteers two to three times a week on the trains.
